Adelaida is married with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Adelaida is 57 years old and has one child who is in school.

Adelaida has an ambulatory business vending bananas in the Philippines. Adelaida requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase an additional stocks of bananas to sell.

Adelaida has been in this business for six years. In the future, Adelaida would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional bananas to sell

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion is 52 years-old and married with four children. With one child in school, Asuncion works very hard to provide for them.

Asuncion runs a sari sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy items to sell such as shampoo, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store.

Asuncion has been in this business for 12 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, curls, eggs, etc. 

In the future, Asuncion would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon is a 34 year old married woman with 4 children. The oldest child is 14 years old and the youngest is 8.

Corazon is a farmer working in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She grows rice and corn crops at her farm. Corazon sells her harvest to rice traders and earns about 30000 PHP per month. Corazon has requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

In the future, Corazon hopes for her children to finish school and to be successful.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seed and fertilizers so her crop can grow well.

loans.name: Nhek

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhek, age 61 years-old, is the mother of six children.  She is from Baray district of Kompong Tom Province.

Since 2000, she has sold fish and vegetables in Baray market and she can earn a profit of $2 per day. 

Her husband is 56-years old and is a domestic farmer.  He also catches fish in and around ponds and rivers.  He earns a profit of $2 per day also. They have given birth to six children, five unmarried and one married. Three of the children are employed in different occupations to generate income.  Mrs. Nhek requests a loan in the amount of $800 for the purpose of purchasing a boat and farming. With the rest of the loan, she hopes to build a new restroom for her family’s use.

loans.use: to purchase a boat, to plant a rice crop and to build a new restroom for her family’s use.

loans.name: Tân's Group

texts.en:
Tân is a 46 year-old male living in a town in Yên Phong district - Băc Ninh province.  Tân is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Thôn Đông - nhóm 04 (4).

Tân is married and has two school-aged children.  To making a living, Tân owns and operates a business providing cargo transport services to local community members.  Tânơ has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 4.200.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2010, Tân joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Tân has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase equipment to improve the business.  He is now requesting a new loan of 7.392.000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  The loan will be the second loan taken by the borrower from SEDA.  Tân plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Phương  is a 31 year-old female who is requesting a 8.736.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail shop selling soft drinks and confectionery.

2.  Đức  is a 37 year-old female who is requesting a 8.288.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall selling chicken and duck eggs.

3.  Hiền is a 32 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock including quail.

4.  Thêm  is a 34 year-old female who is requesting a 7.392.000 VND loan to support her business manufacturing and selling food such as pork.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Tânơ 0 (0) là 46 tuổi nam.  Anh ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong district - Băc Ninh province.  Tânơ là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Thôn Đông - nhóm 04 (4).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ vận chuyển hàng hóa cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Tânơ thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Tânơ kiếm được khoảng 4.200.000 VND.  Vào 2010, Tânơ đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  điều kiện và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Tânơ đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thiết bị để cải thiện công việc kinh doanh.  Anh ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.392.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Phương là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 8.736.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


2.  Đức là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm trứng gà, trứng vịt.


3.  Hiền là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc như nuôi chim cút.


4.  Thêm  là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn như T.t lợn.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to provide cargo transport services to local community members.

loans.name: Luch

texts.en:
Mrs. Luch, 25 years-old, lives in Baray, Kampong Tom Province. She sells spoiled and roasted corns in her community. She is able to make a profit of average of $3 per day. 

Since 2000, Mrs. Luch’s husband has been working in the industry sector as a local garment factory worker in Phnom Penh. He can earn $4 per day. She will use part of this loan to buy land for filling the pond in order to build a new house and also to purchase more corn to sell.

In the future, she wishes to buy more items to sell, to enlarge her current house, and to support her kids to finish a high level of education.

loans.use: to buy land for filling the pond in order to build a new house and also to purchase more corn to sell.

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is a hardworking 41 year old business man. He is married and blessed with three children.  For the  last three years he has been distributing water. He gets extra income from his rental houses.  In the next 5 years Evans wants to have opened up another water point and his dream is to expand his business beyond the region he is operating in now.
Evans is requesting  a loan of 10000 Kenya shillings to buy water pipes, cement and sand. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for advancing him finances to inject into his business.

loans.use: to buy water pipes, cement and sand

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 31-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She has five children between the ages of 13 months and 10 years. All are in school but the youngest. For the past four years, Mary and her husband have been running a business selling secondhand shoes. This business has helped them meet the needs of their family. Mary needs this loan to buy more shoes to make more profit. With the profit, she will pay for her children’s school fees. This loan will help Mary expand her business in the future and continue to provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more secondhand shoes.

loans.name: Consolee

texts.en: Consolee is a 37-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She is married and has six children between the ages of 1.5 years and 15 years old. Her husband is a teacher at secondary school, and all of her children are in school except the youngest one. Since 1997, she has owned a general store. This successful business has enabled her to save for her children and provide for the well-being of her family. Consolee will use this loan to purchase more items to sell in her store to meet the demand of her customers. She plans to continue to use the profits to provide for her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im, 61, resides in the Prey Chor district of Kampong Cham Province. Her core income for her whole family comes from planting rice crops and vegetables. She has been working at this job since 1990. She can earn $0.75 per day. Her husband also helps support her on the farm field and makes around US $0.75 each day. They have three children. One of the children is single and two are married. One of them works as a sewing factory worker in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. Mrs. Im would like to borrow some funds from Kiva to buy cabbage seed, cask, and fertilizers. She will use the remainder of the funds to buy some poles to decorate her old house. Mrs. Im appears in the photo with her husband.

loans.use: to buy cabbage seed, cask, and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ganchina

texts.ru: Ганчина проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 23 года. Она замужем. У нее детей нет. Она занимается животноводством. Разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. В основном она закупает телят, откармливает и продает их по более выгодной цене. В этой области она уже два года. В продвижении ее деятельности ей помогает ее муж. Она берет кредит для закупа двух голов телят.
texts.en: Ganchina lives in the Shahrituz district.  She is 23 years old, married and has no children.  She is involved in animal husbandry and breeds cattle at her home.  She primarily buys calves, fattens them up and sells them at a more profitable price.  She has been in this business for two years.  Ganchina's husband helps her with growing her business.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of two calves.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Rosine

texts.en:
Rosine is a 30-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She has a child who is 4 and in school. Her husband is a construction worker. For the past 10 years, Rosine has been running a business as a tailor. The success of her business has enabled her to take care of her child.

She will use the requested loan to purchase a specialty sewing machine that can create hems. This will improve the quality of her product and ensure that she continues to expand her client base. With the profits from this business, she plans to provide for her family, pay for her child’s school fees, and accumulate savings. Her goal as a savvy businesswoman is to one day open up her own workshop.

loans.use: to purchase a specialty sewing machine to sew hems

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine is a 36-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She has five children between the ages of 3 and 12 years old. All of her children are in school except for the youngest two. Her husband is a taxi driver. 

Since 2004, Clementine has been selling banana beers locally. This business has helped her meet the needs of her family. She requested this loan so that she can buy more bananas in order to generate more profits. With the profits from her business, she will save and continue to provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase bananas that she will use to make beer

loans.name: Kuku's Group

texts.en:
Microfinance in Kyrgyzstan provides small loans to entrepreneurs with small and mid-sized businesses, which comprise 40% of the country’s businesses. It is especially crucial for women, who are vulnerable but eager and full of enthusiasm to start up their own independent businesses. 

Kuku, 66, is the leader of this group. She is a widow and brought up three kids, the youngest of whom is a high school freshman. Her sons live independently in the capital, while Kuku together with her daughter stays in a small fishing town Balykchi, which attracts thousands of tourists both from Kyrgyzstan and abroad. The constant flow of tourists is a key to Kuku’s business success. 

As she is already retired, all she does is manage her orchard with plenty of fruits and vegetables. This year she was blessed with a very rich harvest of apricot and apples. They do not stay in a warehouse for long and get sold very easily. A monthly profit of 3,700 soms allowed her to purchase new furniture for the house and other necessary things. This year’s savings plus the loan that Kuku is requesting from Kiva lenders will help her finance a trip to her sons in the capital of Bishkek and spend some time with them there. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
	
 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to cover transportation costs so she can visit her sons

loans.name: Téné

texts.fr:
Mme Téné est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé à 10ans et le moins âgé a 03ans. Un va à l’école et elle a 04 personne a sa charge.

Elle vend des pagnes et des mèches depuis 05 ans. Mme s’approvisionne au marché du secteur 10 de Ouagadougou. Ses clients sont ses voisins, ses amies et toute personne ambulante.

Elle veut s’acheter 10 pièces de pagnes et un carton de mèches. 

Mme aide son mari dans l’entretien de la famille avec ses bénéfices. Elle ambitionne ouvrir une grande boutique de pagnes, de produits de beauté et de mèches. Et aussi aider à la scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en: Ms. Téné is married and the mother of two children. The elder is 10 years old, and the younger is three. One goes to school. Téné has four persons to support. She has been selling pagnes (colorful West African cloth) and hair extensions for five years. She gets her supplies at the market of Sector 10 of Ouagadougou. Her customers are her neighbors, friend, and anyone walking by. She want to buy ten lengths of pagne cloth and a box of hair extensions. With her profits, Téné helps out her husband in caring for the family. Her ambition is to open a large store selling pagne cloth, beauty products, and hair extensions, and also to help cover her children's schooling costs.

loans.use: to buy a half-bale of 'pagne' cloth and a box of hair extensions

loans.name: Jean Damascene

texts.en:
Jean Damascene is a 29 year old Rwandan entrepreneur with 3 children between the ages of 14 months and 6 years. The oldest one is in school. 

For the past year,he has been running a general store with his wife.This business has enabled him to develop him self and provide for his children.

He will use this loan to purchase more goods for sell in the store.As his profits increase,he will be able to expand the business and continue to provide for his family.

loans.use: To purchase more goods that she will sell in her general store

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim, age 50, has been living in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. Her job is a domestic rice farmer and she has been operating this sector for many years. She can earn $2 per day. Her husband also assists her in the crop-planting business and he can earn $4 per day. They have seven children. Five of the children are single and two are already married and live in their own houses. Two of their children work as construction workers. Mrs. Sim requests $600 to purchase house construction materials.

loans.use: to purchase house construction materials.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a 47-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She has six children between the ages of 5 and 18 and they are all in school apart from the youngest. Her husband works in a secondary school as teacher.

For the past 17 years, Catherine has been running a bar selling beer. This business has helped her pay school fees for her children, feed her family, and meet their needs. She will use the requested loan to buy a variety of beers that will allow her meet the growing demand of her business. The profits from her business will allow her to continue to provide for her family and pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more beer for resale

loans.name: Buntuuse Farmers Association Group

texts.en:
Farming has been 60-year-old Lawrence's means of livelihood for close to 3 years in Lugazi. While Lugazi is not anywhere near the food basket districts of Uganda, many of the indigenous people there have recently embraced commercial farming though most of it is on a small scale. Many natives principally grow sugar cane. The two sugar cane factories in the district provide a market for most of these sugar cane farmers. Recently however many natives have taken to growing other cash crops such as bananas, cassava, maize, coffee and cabbage.

Lawrence, who is an affable father of 7 buoyant and high spirited children, says that notwithstanding the high cost of doing business in the country, he remains upbeat about the growth of his business. From the beginning, he found it formidable to obtain a footing in a business which was already highly competitive. Unwavering diligence, determination, perseverance and will power have been Lawrence's magic formula for his fledgling success. 

Prior to taking root in this enterprise, Lawrence was working in a small retail trade. The fact that foods such as bananas, maize and coffee sell highly in the food markets in this part of the country has profoundly emboldened Lawrence. Out of this business on a weekly basis, Lawrence is able to make sales profits to the tune of 400,000 Ugandan shillings. He reckons he will be able to make more than he currently makes if he can apply high grade manure in his farm to ensure good harvests. On the side, he also ekes out additional income from a milk sales business. Lawrence says he is requesting this Kiva loan to purchase high grade manure for his farm. Lawrence’s group is taking its fourth loan from Pearl Microfinance now and their track record in repaying their loans has been commendable.

loans.use: to purchase high grade manure for his farm

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
This is Rosario, 65, a resident of Binondo, Manila, Philippines. She is a mother of three children, all of whom are already in college, and married to Vinerando, a vendor. By the grace of God, Rosario has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Rosario as she herself has been an undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Rosario operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part of the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice costs less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 35,000. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Rosario dreams to be able to give her children a high quality education through all of her hard work. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products she uses in her food stall

loans.name: Nurgul

texts.en:
Women of Central Asian countries are mostly involved in several industries like textile, food production, medicine and teaching. A big portion is on behalf of trade. 

Nurgul, 43, has experience in borrowing loans because she started a business breeding and selling cattle in 1999 thanks to a loan borrowed from a local bank. Soon Nurgul purchased a small pavilion where she could promote and sell food products. She said that twelve years of experience in this business have taught her many lessons. Every day work and patience in the past do not allow her to make mistakes in the present. She shares her knowledge with younger generations, and it helps them not to repeat Nurgul’s mistakes. Her monthly income generated from selling food products comprises 39,000 soms. Nurgul plans to use these funds plus those acquired from Kiva lenders for investing in goods circulation and in a purchase of a house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
	
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs and ultimately purchase a house

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Since 1979, Mrs. Sam, 48, has been living in the Prey Chor district. She currently works in the farming business as a rice cultivator. She is able to earn an income of approximately $1 per day to cover the family’s needs. They have six single children.  Two of their kids are working as security guards in Phnom Penh. They get a specific salary every month. From their low income, they always contribute some to Mrs. Sam to be used for the entire family. Mrs. Sam is requesting a loan to purchase many sacks of fertilizers, seeds, and other farming materials.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds, and other farming materials.

loans.name: Kubriyokhon

texts.ru: Кубрёхон проживает в городе Исфара. Ей 43 года. Она замужем. Ее муж находится на заработках в России. У нее двое детей. Сама она занимается торговлей. У нее имеется магазин, где она продает женские национальные платья. Этим видом деятельности она занимается 10 лет. Она берет кредит для покупки платьев с вышивками.
texts.en: Kubriyokhon lives in the city of Isfara.  She is 43 years old, married and has two children.  Her husband currently works in Russia.  Kubriyokhon is involved in retail sales.  She has a store, where she sells women's national dresses.  She has been involved in this business for ten years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of embroidered dresses.

loans.use: to purchase embroidered dresses

loans.name: Norie

texts.en:
This is Norie, 44, a resident of Baseco Port Area, Manila, Philippines. He is single but works hard to sustain himself and to continually provide income for his everyday expenses, although he shares his income with his family. Norie operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, cooking oil, or an egg. Norie earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. 

Aside from the store, he has a food stall where one can buy home-cooked meals. His store is located adjacent to his house. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. Norie earns a minimum of PHP 750 in sales every day.

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting a loan of PHP 50,000. He will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory. A portion of the loan will also be used to buy quantities of products like meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. Norie hopes to be able to expand soon and live a happy life. He faithfully meets with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week, where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loan

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and other products for his store

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
This is Lea, 32, a resident of Baseco, Manila, Philippines. She is a mother of one and married to Renato, a security guard. She and her husband manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lea operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, cooking oil, or an egg. Lea earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 533 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 35,000. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and charcoal to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Lea hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her child a high quality education through all of her hard work. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and other products for her store

loans.name: Shaimbubu's Group

texts.en: Summertime is usually a time when price jumps for local beef products. It is caused by keeping all livestock in highland pastures called jailoo for fattening. Shaimbubu, 64, is the leader of this group. She is a widow and has a 29-year-old son who is a construction worker. Shaimbubu is retired and gets a monthly pension of around 3,200 soms and an additional 1,400 soms from cattle breeding. At the moment, just like other shepherds, Shaimbubu has sent her livestock of eight head to jailoo in order to keep them in natural conditions so they grow big. Meanwhile, she is busy with her orchard which produced plenty of apricots this year. Since the fruit is very perishable, she tries to sell quickly at the best price offered. Shaimbubu has been in this business for 31 years and is happy with what she has been doing. She asks for a loan so that she can finance the purchase of new livestock, which she plans to also send to jailoo. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young and ambitious socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Ork

texts.en: Mrs. Ork is a rice farmer who lives in the Prey Chor district. To make a living, she and her husband have experience in the farming business. She learned how to plant crops from her parents when they were young. On average, Mrs. Ork can make around $1 per day. Mrs. Ork will be using the loan that she is requesting to buy some farming material and seeds for planting during the heavy rain because it is good for planting her crops. The humble couple has three single children. Mrs. Ork, her husband and her two kids appear in the photograph.

loans.use: to buy some farming material and seeds for planting

loans.name: Orazkhan's Group

texts.en: According to statistics, women in Central Asia are two times less likely to open businesses than men. There are a number of reasons, like fear of risk and lack of knowledge about managing a business. However, Orazkhan is not among those people. Orazkhan, 42, is the leader of this group. She knows that a good business should be profitable, both for her and society. Four years ago, while breeding and reselling cattle which brought only intermittent income, she decided to start another type of profitable business – a chicken farm. With an initial startup capital of 6,000 soms, Orazkhan purchased 60 productive chickens. After two months of keeping the poultry in warm and sanitized conditions, the hens reached a state of giving at least two eggs a day each. Besides distributing eggs to her neighbors at market price, Orazkhan usually has more left for her family’s consumption. The business helps her provide her family with nutritious food like chicken and diversify the menu. Throughout these four years, Orazkhan has been making 6,000 - 7,000 soms income per month, which is quite enough to help her husband and their daughter. The loan requested by Orazkhan will be invested into development of the business and buying more chickens. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young and ambitious socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase chickens.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Mrs. Ven is a 30-year-old married woman. She now lives in Prey Chor district. Mrs. Ven and her husband have done most of their business as local farmers. They can earn $2.50 per day to use for the family expenses. They have two single children who are still learning in school. Mrs. Ven is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and to pay for the plowing costs she hired.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay for plowing costs.

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is 40 years old. He is unmarried and lives with his mother in the village of Marani in West Georgia. Alexander’s mother is retired. As a family living under the poverty level, they receive state social assistance on a monthly basis. 

Alexander’s profession is house-painting. He works in the village, if there are relevant orders. Also the family has 2 milk cows. Alexander’s mother produces and sells 40 kg of cheese per month. They own a 1 hectare maize corn-field and sell 800 kg maize each season. The total average monthly income of the family is approximately 400 Laris. 

Alexander plans to marry in the near future, which is the main reason why he decided to renovate his house and make it more comfortable for a just married couple. With the requested credit he will purchase construction materials and will renovate the house himself.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for house renovation

loans.name: Oreofe Group

texts.fr: OREOFE est un groupement constitué de trente deux personnes et dont la représentante (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est nommée Ida. Les membres du groupe résident dans le même quartier au Bénin et mènent chacune des activités génératrices de revenus. Ces membres ont décidé de mettre ensemble leur énergie afin de mieux réussir. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupement sollicite pour la première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ida est âgée de 28 ans et est mariée à un électricien du nom de Jacques. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, dont un est leur propre enfant. Aucun des enfants n'est scolarisé. Ida vit ensemble avec sa famille, et assure ensemble avec son mari les diverses charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Pour y arriver, Ida produit de l'huile de palme, qu'elle vend à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Ida vend de riz frit. Ida s'approvisionne dans le Sud du Bénin. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Ida et aux autres membres du groupement OREOFE, de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en: «Oreofe » is a group composed of 32 individuals whose representative (the woman raising her hand in the photo) is named Ida. The group members live in the same neighborhood in Benin and each earn an income. They have decided to join forces in order to achieve better results. In order to bolster their working capital, this group is seeking its first loan from ALIDé. Ida is 28 years old and is married to Jacques, an electrician. They have four children in their charge, one of whom is their own child. None of the children is in school. Ida lives together with her family and provides for the mainly needs jointly with her husband, thanks to the income from her business. Ida makes palm oil and sells it out of her home. As a side activity, she also sells fried rice. Ida stocks up in the South of Benin. This first loan will help Ida and other members of the “Oreofe” group to expand their business and increase their customer numbers and their revenues

loans.use: to buy palm fruit for the production of palm oil

loans.name: Chon

texts.en: Mrs. Chon, 31, resides in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. She has a stone mortar business at home. She and her husband often help each other in the stone mortar selling business. They have three children, all of whom are single and attend the local school. Mrs. Chon will be using the loan to purchase a swooped stone machine.

loans.use: to purchase a swooped stone machine.

loans.name: Mufariji Group

texts.fr: La cliente Mapendo, leader du groupe d’affaire « Mufariji », est entrepreneur, âgée de 45 ans, mariée, mère de 12 enfants qui étudient tous et dont  3 autres ont déjà leurs propres foyers. Elle est  vendeuse des bananes. Son mari est un tailleur couturier. Elle installe ses bananes au marché communal de Katindo-Alanine.  Il y a 10 ans révolus qu’elle exerce ces petites activités génératrices de revenus de ce genre. Cependant, elle vient de réaliser  10 cycles avec le crédit de Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir  de s’approvisionner avec  les fruits (4 régimes de bananes, 1 paniers des avocats) à marchander.  En plus, elle ambitionne scolariser ses enfants et  développer une autre entreprise.  La cliente remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire « Mufariji » est majoritairement féminins.
texts.en:
Mapendo is a client and the leader of the business group "Mufariji". She is an entrepreneur, 45 years old, married, and the mother of twelve children who have all had schooling. Three of them already have their own homes. 

Mapendo sells bananas, and her husband is a tailor-clothier. She sets up her bananas at the community market of Katindo-Alanine. She has been operating small revenue-generating businesses of these types for ten years. However, she has just completed ten loan cycles with Hekima. This new loan must serve to buy a supply of fruit (4 bunches of bananas and a basket of avocados) to be sold. In addition, her ambition is to educate her children and to develop another enterprise.

Our client thanks Hekima for its actions favoring poor women who are excluded from traditional banks. It is appropriate to note that the business group Mufariji is composed mostly of women.

loans.use: to buy 4 bunches of bananas and a basket of avocados

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Hiền's Group

texts.en:
Hien is 45 years old. She lives in Thon Đong village. She is married with two children. She is a farmer who not only grows rice and wheat but raises chickens and pigs as well. She is part of the loan at the Center for SEDA 2011. This is her first loan and she wishes to borrow 5,152,000 VND to expand her business and buy feed for her chickens and pigs. 

 She is the leader of the five–member group loan. The other borrowers in her group are as follows:
 
 Nhi is 22 years old. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VNĐ to purchase scrap. 

 Thương is 24 years old. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VNĐ to buy feed for her chickens. 

 Hien is 32 years old. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VNĐ to buy to prepare breakfast foods to sell such as porridge.
 
 Hương is 26 years old. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VNĐ to buy food for her chickens and pigs

loans.use: to purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mrs. Ros has been living in the Dongkor commune in Phnom Penh City. She is a sewing factory worker and she always gets a specific salary per month. She earns $3 per day. Her husband works as a local construction worker in Phnom Penh. He earns $4 per day. They have three children. Two of the children are single and one is married. One of the three children is working as a garment factory worker. Mrs. Ros has requested $600 to purchase a motorbike for her kids to drive to their work location.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her kids

loans.name: Julienne

texts.en:
Julienne is a 54-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She has three children between the ages of 17 and 33 years old.  She is a widow. 

Since 1997, she has been selling traditional cloth called bitenge.  Her business is going well and it has enabled her to look after her children.  

She will use this loan to buy more bitenge, from which she will generate more profits.  With the profits she will pay school fees for her children and continue to provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase traditional cloth called bitenge that she will sell

loans.name: Gularus

texts.ru: Гуларус проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 29 лет. Замужем, имеет троих детей. Она вместе с мужем занимается торговлей. У нее высшее педагогическое образование. Она три года проработала по профессии. Сейчас у нее имеется магазин, где она продает хозяйственные товары. Этим видом деятельности она занимается уже три года. Кредит берет для приобретения тарелок, бокалов, чайников и пиялок (чайной чашки).
texts.en: Gularus lives in the Shahrituz district.  She is 29 years old, married and has three children.  She and her husband are involved in retail sales.  She has a higher education as a teacher.  Gularus spent three years working in that profession.  Today, she has a store, where she sells household goods.  She has been in this business for three years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of plates, glasses, teapots and piyalkas (tea cups).

loans.use: to purchase plates, glasses, teapots and piyalkas (tea cups)

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en:
Gertrude is a 33-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She is divorced and has three children who are between the ages of 7 and 14. All of her children are in school. For the past five years, she has been running a business selling clothes, small fish and sunflower oil. The profits generated from this business have enabled her to take care of her children and make savings.

Gertrude will use this loan to purchase more clothes, fish, and sunflower oil that she sources from Burundi and Uganda. She hopes to use the future profits from her business to renovate her house. As a businesswoman, she aspires to some day source her goods from Dubai.

loans.use: to purchase additional clothes, fish and sunflower oil that she will sell.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana is from the village of Didi Jikhaishi, West Georgia. She is 44 years old, married and lives with her family:  husband, Victor; 16-year-old son and 76-year-old father. Nana works as a foreign language teacher in a local school. Victor serves in the army. Nana’s son goes to school and her father is retired. 

Nana is running the agricultural business of the family. They have six milk cows and two calves. She sells approximately 120 kg of cheese per month at a local open market. Also, the family owns a pig and sells 12 - 14 piglets per month. Nana’s husband works in the family-owned cornfield, where 2 - 3 tonnes of maize are harvested for the season. The total harvest is used on the farm for feeding the animals. 

With the requested loan, Nana plans to purchase construction materials for a new cattle shed. The existing one is already too small and doesn’t allow Nana to plan future expansion of the family’s farming activities. In the future, Nana is going to purchase additional cows so she can produce and sell more cheese. In a year, Nana will need more financial resources, as she will have to pay school fees for her son.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for cattle shed construction.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more crates of both hard and soft beverages like sodas and beer to resell

loans.name: Pascasie

texts.en:
Pascasie is a 26-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur. She is married. She and her husband have seven children between the ages of 3.5 and 14 years old and some she has adopted. All the children are in school.  

For the past eight years, Pascasie has been running a business selling foodstuffs. This business has enabled her to meet the needs of her family.  

She needs this loan to buy more foodstuffs in order to increase her profits.  With the profits, she will pay for her children’s school fees.

 This loan will help her realize her goal of expanding her business in the future and continuing to provide for her many children.

loans.use: To purchase additional foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ararat

texts.ru:
Арарат родился в 1955 г.и проживает в городе Капане. Он окончил среднюю школу села Шрвенанц, а после получил техническое образование по специальности радиоэлектротехник. Женат, имеет двух детей: сына и дочь. Дочка замужем и живет отдельно со своей семьей. Жена домохозяйка, сын работает вместе с отцом в автомастерской инкассации банка. Параллельно со своей работой, Арарат занимается частным бизнесом. 5 лет назад он открыл собственную автомастерскую, в которой работает по вечерам, после рабочего дня и по выходным. Имеет своих постоянных клиентов и на полученную прибыль содержит свою семью. 
Сумма кредита необходима Арарату для приобретения домкрата, что позволит увеличить количество клиентов и уровень их обслуживания.
texts.en: Ararat was born in 1955 in the city of Kapan.  He finished a secondary school in the Shrvenants village and then obtained a technical education in the radio elecrtician field.  He is married and has two children, a son and a daughter.  The daughter is married and lives separately with her family.  Ararat's wife is a homemaker, and their son works together with his father at an auto shop.  Parallel to his job, Ararat is involved in a private business.  He opened his own auto repair shop five years ago, where he works in the evenings, after his work day and on the weekends.  He has consistent customers and uses the profits to support his family.  Ararat needs a loan to purchase a hoisting jack in order to increase his customer base and the level of service.

loans.use: To buy hoisting jack for his auto repair shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase one milking cow and two cattle

loans.name: Bendu

texts.en: Bendu is 48 years old and lives in Jacob Town. She is married and has two children who are 2 and 10 years old. Both of them are attending school. For the past five years now, she has been selling Lappa (a traditional cloth) and slippers in the local market. Sometimes she faces a lot of problems with the hiking of prices. She is requesting a loan to purchase more Lappa and slippers for her business. She plans to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more Lappa and slippers to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase more inventory of dishes

loans.name: Jesutogbe 1 Group

texts.fr: JESUTOGBE 1 est un groupe de huit personnes, dont les membres résident dans la même agglomération au Bénin et mènent des activités complémentaires. La représentante du groupe, Philomène(dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 41 ans et est mariée à un tailleur du nom de Antonin. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Philomène et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants. Philomène n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Il y a près de vingt cinq ans que Philomène mène comme activité la vente de produits divers et des cartes de recharges téléphoniques à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Philomène vend de l'eau glacée à son domicile ; ce qui lui permet de subvenir sans grande difficulté à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Philomène s’approvisionne au Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Philomène sollicite un crédit avec les autres membres du groupe JESUTOGBE 1. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: The Jesutogbe 1 group comprises eight people who all live in the same town in Benin and run complementary businesses. The group leader, Philomène (with the raised hand in the photo), is 41 years old and married to a tailor named Antonin. The couple have four children, all of whom are in their care and attend school. Philomène and her husband live together with their children. Philomène only attended primary school. For close to 25 years, she has run a business selling various items and rechargeable phone cards at her home. In addition, she also sells ice water at her home; this allows her to provide for herself and her children without too much difficulty. Philomène gets her supplies in Benin. With the goal of satisfying her clientele, she is seeking a loan along with the other members of the Jesutogbe 1 group. This loan will allow them to better respond to the needs of their clientele and generate greater profits.

loans.use: To buy various items and rechargeable phone cards.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase ten sheep and two cattle

loans.name: Sop Moustapha Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Moustapha est créé depuis le 27 décembre 2010, il est constitué de dix neuf femmes issues du même village qui font du petit commerce et de l'agriculture.


La responsable Anta Dame est âgée de 31 ans, mariée mère de trois enfants, elle mène une activité maraîchère et posséde un petit lopin de terre,elle a une bonne expérience. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite habillée en boubou rayures vert blanc et couverte d'un châle blanc. 


Elle achéte ses semences et produits phytosanitaires dans la ville et ses récoltes sont vendus au marché du village.


Elle envisage avec son prêt se procurer plus de semences et aussi diversifier son activité en achetant divers produits pour faire du petit commerce.


Elle souhaite avec les bénéfices attendus subvenir aux besoins de sa famille sur le plan scolaire et sanitaire.
texts.en:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Moustapha est créé depuis le 27 décembre 2010, il est constitué de dix neuf femmes issues du même village qui font du petit commerce et de l'agriculture.


La responsable Anta Dame est âgée de 31 ans, mariée mère de trois enfants, elle mène une activité maraîchère et posséde un petit lopin de terre,elle a une bonne expérience. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite habillée en boubou rayures vert blanc et couverte d'un châle blanc. 


Elle achéte ses semences et produits phytosanitaires dans la ville et ses récoltes sont vendus au marché du village.


Elle envisage avec son prêt se procurer plus de semences et aussi diversifier son activité en achetant divers produits pour faire du petit commerce.


Elle souhaite avec les bénéfices attendus subvenir aux besoins de sa famille sur le plan scolaire et sanitaire.

loans.use: ACHETER DES  INTRANTS POUR SON MARAÎCHAGE.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more spices, oil and rice for her business.

loans.name: Raul

texts.en:
Raul is from the village of Zanati, West Georgia. He is 46 years old and lives with his wife, Irma. Raul works as a construction worker in the village, when there are orders. Also, he is involved in the family agricultural business. They have two milk cows and three calves, and produce and sell 35 kg of cheese per month at a local open market. Also, Raul and Irma have a pig and sell 12-16 piglets per year. Along with the above, Raul grows bamboo trees on a family-owned 0.5 hectare plot. He sells 500-600 bamboo poles per year, which are used for furniture production. The average total monthly income of the family is 550 laris. 

With the requested loan, Raul plans to purchase a car. He will use it for transportation of the family farm products (cheese and bamboos) to nearby towns, where he can sell them for a higher price than locally in the village. It will positively impact the income of the family. Raul and Irma will use the increase in income for house renovation.

loans.use: to purchase a car for farm products transportation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase three cattle and fodder

loans.name: Viateur

texts.fr: Viateur est un salarie, il est célibataire. Il  a   43ans, il a 1 enfant de 12 ans, et son enfant étudier. Il  a 6 ans des études secondaires, il est ne au République Démocratique du Congo(RDC). C’est son quatrième cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit pour acheter des matériels de construire une maison destine à la location  (planche, clous, sable, tôles,) payer la main d’œuvre. Il  n’a aucune difficulté attendue de non-remboursement de son prêt. Sa stratégie pour la croissance de son business est de renouvelle sa maison pour la valoriser pour que le revenu venant de la location soit élevé. Pour ses ambitions il voudrait construire des salles polyvalentes à louer, construire d’autre maison pour sa famille, et payer le minerval pour son enfant.
texts.en:
Viateur is a salaried worker. He is single, 43 years old and has one child, who is 12 years old and a student. He was born in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and has 6 years of secondary education. 

This is his 4th loan cycle with ACB. He will use the loan to buy material to build a house to rent out (wood, nails, sand, sheet metal..), and to pay for labor costs. He does not anticipate any difficulty in paying back the loan. His strategy for increasing his business is to renovate his house, increasing its value so that rental income will go up.  His ambition is to build multi-purpose rooms to rent out, to build another house for his family and to pay his son's school fees.

loans.use: to buy materials to build a house to rent out (wood, nails, sand, sheet metal) and to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase organic fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Jesutogbe 4 Group

texts.fr: JESUTOGBE 4 est un groupe de huit personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante du groupe, Emilienne (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 46 ans et est mariée à un pêcheur du nom de Barnabé. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux à leur charge. Emilienne et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges des enfants. Emilienne n'est jamais allé à l'école.  Il y a une trentaine d'année que Emilienne vend des produits vivriers et aussi des poissons frais à son domicile. Emilienne exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Emilienne s’approvisionne au Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Emilienne sollicite une autre crédit avec les membres du groupe JESUTOGBE 4. Ce crédit leur servira à renforcer leur fonds de roulement, afin de mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et de se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: The Jesutogbe 4 group comprises eight people who all live in the same area in Benin. The group leader, Emilienne (with the raised hand in the photo), is 46 years old and married to a fisherman named Barnabé. The couple have four children, all of whom are in school and two of whom are in the care of their parents. Emilienne and her husband live together with their children and take care of the various needs of the children. Emilienne never attended school. For about thirty years, she has sold food items as well as fresh fish at her home. Emilienne runs this business passionately, and it allows her to provide for herself and her children. She gets her supplies in Benin. With the goal of satisfying her clientele, Emilienne is seeking another loan along with the rest of the members of the Jesutogbe 4 group. This loan will allow them to strengthen their working capital in order to better respond to the needs of their clientele and generate higher profits.

loans.use: To buy various food items and fresh fish.

loans.name: Asmahan

texts.en:
Asmahan has 20 years of experience working in selling beauty products and cosmetics to locA. customers. She works on a freelance basis. Asmahan is a 51-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband and three children, one of whom is still attending school. With her requested loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l., she will invest in expanding her inventory selection. 

Women continue to play an important role in Lebanese society, especially in the development of the family. Women are able to serve as strong role models for their children while also helping to supplement their household incomes. In almost all parts of Lebanon, demand for beauty and fashion products continues to be high.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her inventory selection.

loans.name: Wilter

texts.en: Wilter is a hardworking 27-year-old business lady. She is married and blessed with three school-going children, aged 10, 6 and 3. Since the year 2005, she has been making ends meet by running a general shop. She supplements her income from this venture with the earnings she makes from engaging in the transport industry with her matatu (minibus). She harbors a dream that in the next five years, she would have upgraded her store into a supermarket. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 Kenya shillings to buy maize flour, cooking oil, sugar, etc. Her business has been able to expand tremendously, and she credits this to the support she gets from Faulu Kenya.

loans.use: to buy maize flour, cooking oil, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Potola

texts.en:
Potola comes from the village of Nogha, West Georgia. She is 62 years old and lives with her mother-in-law in the village. 

Potola used to work as cashier, but at the moment, she is retired and is mainly busy with her agricultural business. Potola has four milk cows and two calves. She produces and sells 70 – 80 kg of cheese at the local open market. Also, Potola grows 500 nut trees and sells approximately 400 kg of nuts per year. Along with the above-mentioned things, Potola has a couple of hens and turkeys. She sells eggs at the local market. The total monthly income of the family, including the pension of Potola’s mother-in-law, is 300 Laris. 

Potola plans to increase the amount of hens and turkeys on her farm, but her problem is that the fence of the yard is already old and broken, and there is the risk that some of the hens and turkeys may go through it and get lost. Because of this reason, Potola requested credit for renovation of the fence. After she has a new fence, she will increase the amount of hens and turkeys and will be able to sell more eggs. It will positively impact her income. Potola plans to use the increased income for a house renovation to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase materials for a fence renovation to keep more hens and turkeys.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is 35 years old and lives in Jacob Town. She is married, and her husband is a businessman. They both have two children, and all of their children are attending school. 

For three years now, Victoria has been selling dry goods on a table in the market, where she sells many items such as rice, oil, soap, etc. One of the most inspiring thing is that her business helps her earn more money for herself. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, oil, soap, etc., for her business. She plans to buy a car in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, oil, soap, etc., for her business.

loans.name: Brenda's Group

texts.en:
Brenda‘s group is comprised of two hard-working women. Brenda is 17 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala central region of Uganda. Brenda has a small retail shop business that sells sugar. She has had this business for five years. She sells tap water as her second business.  

To help expand her business, Brenda has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like sugar for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Brenda hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family.  In the future, Brenda hopes to own a plot of land. Brenda is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving in her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like sugar for resale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to  purchase better spare parts and tires for his motorcycle

loans.name: Gerges

texts.en:
Gerges is a 21-year-old single man living with one parent and two siblings. He is from Lebanon. 

In 2009, he started running his own business. He works as a female hairdresser serving clients at their domiciles. His business income is very important because he helps his father with the household expenses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new hairdressing tools and supplies. He intends to expand his business operation further and hopes to be able to open a formA. beauty salon in the coming years.

loans.use: to purchase new hairdressing tools and supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase 20 gallons of red oil.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a hardworking 59-year-old businesswoman. She is widowed and blessed with 10 children between 40 and 17 years old. She has been engaged for the last 11 years in dairy farming to provide for her family. She wants in the next five years to have increased her herd to five cattle so that she is able to be financially stable. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy animal feed. She is grateful to Faulu Kenya for introducing her to a saving culture.

loans.use: to buy animal feed

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like sugar to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cosmetics on special offer

loans.name: Ritah

texts.en:
Ritah is 16 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Ritah has a business of a small hotel (restaurant), which she has had for two years.         

To help expand her business, Ritah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase food to cook for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Ritah hopes to generate greater profits and pay for her school fees.  In the future, Ritah hopes to study and become a nurse.  Ritah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase food to cook and sell

loans.name: Nounagnon Adjadji Bata Group

texts.fr: NOUNAGNON ADJADJI BATA est un groupement constitué de dix sept personnes et dont la présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est nommée Jacqueline. Les membres du groupe résident dans le même village au Bénin et appartiennent à une même association. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupement sollicite pour la première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Jacqueline est âgée de 36 ans et est mariée à un couturier du nom de Charles. Le couple a trois enfants. Jacqueline vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges du ménage. Pour faire face à ses besoins et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Jacqueline mène comme activité depuis six ans, la vente d'escargots dans sa zone. De façon secondaire, Jacqueline prépare de l'"akassa" (pâte locale faite à base d'amidon de maïs) qu'elle vend dans sa zone. Jacqueline achète ses produits au Bénin. Ce premier prêt permettra certainement à Jacqueline et aux autres membres du groupement NOUNAGNON ADJADJI BATA, de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en: The Nounagnon Adjadji Bata group comprises 17 people and its president (the woman with the raised hand in the photo) is named Jacqueline. The group members live in the same town in Benin and belong to the same association. With the goal of increasing their working capital, this group is seeking its first loan with ALIDÉ. Jacqueline is 36 years old and married to a tailor named Charles. The couple have three children. Jacqueline lives together with her husband and children. The couple provide for the household together. To meet her needs and provide for her children, Jacqueline has run a business selling escargot in her area for six years. Secondarily, she also prepares and sells 'akassa' (a local paste made from cornstarch) in her area. Jacqueline buys her products in Benin. This first loan will certainly allow her and the other members of the Nounagnon Adjadji Bata group to raise the level of their business and increase their clientele and income.

loans.use: To buy 8 sets of 40 snails and one bag of maize.

loans.name: Virgen Del Carmen Group

texts.es:
En un barrio de la ciudad de Paraguarí, se reúne un grupo de mujeres con el fin de interiorizarse sobre el programa ofrecido por la Fundación Paraguaya, de esta forma se dieron cuenta de la excelente oportunidad que les proporcionaría ser parte de la misma, es así que deciden realizar la reunión para la conformación del comité, el cual lleva el nombre de Virgen del Carmen, todas ellas asumen la gran responsabilidad de permanecerse unidas y en constante comunicación ya que es la clave para mantener la unidad de las integrantes, actualmente se encuentran en el cuarto ciclo con calificación excelente, actualmente está conformada por 18 mujeres.
La Sra. Dominga es peluquera, por medio de este trabajo ella logra mantenerse y mantener su negocio. Ella se considera una mujer luchadora, que le gusta lo que hace. Está muy orgullosa de su trabajo, ya que por medio de este puede tener la esperanza de un futuro mejor por medio de los ingresos que este le genera.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de tintes, juegos de tijeras, spray y demás, lo cual le servirá para el ejercicio de su profesión.
texts.en:
In a neighborhood in the city of Paraguarí, a group of women came together with the aim of finding out about the program offered by Fundación Paraguaya.  They came to realize what an excellent opportunity they would be receiving if they joined the program.  They decided to have a meeting and form a committee called 'Virgen del Carmen'.  All of the women accept the great responsibility of remaining united and in constant communication as this is the key to maintaining the unity of the committee's members.  They are currently on their fourth loan cycle with an excellent rating.  The group currently has 18 members.

Dominga is a hair dresser.  Through her work she manages to support herself and keep her business going.  She considers herself to be a tenacious woman who enjoys what she does.  She is very proud of her work since it enables her to have hope for a better future through the income that she makes from her business.

Dominga is requesting a loan to buy dyes, sets of scissors, sprays and other items which will help her to carry out her profession.

loans.use: to buy dyes, scissors, sprays and other utensils

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Jane has a small retail shop that sells sugar, which she has had for two years. To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase essential commodities like sugar for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jane hopes to generate greater profits and buy herself new clothes. In the future, Jane hopes to own a vehicle.

Jane is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her capital. Jane's group is comprised of seven hardworking women.

loans.use: to purchase essential commodities like sugar for resale.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is a single, 26-year-old businessman. He is aggressive, persistent, hardworking and knows what he wants in life. He has been selling secondhand clothes for the last two years to make a living for himself. In the next five years, he wants to have moved to a permanent stall. His dream is to start selling new clothes. 

Isaac is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy secondhand clothes. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for training him in prudent management skills.

loans.use: to buy secondhand clothes.

loans.name: Mohamad Ali

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 20-year-old single man from Lebanon. He is living with his parents and five siblings. This young man has been working in a locA. restaurant since 2009. His business is very essentiA. because, with its income, he is able to help his parents pay his university education fees. As is common among the young Lebanese generation, he has a job and is pursuing his education at the same time. 

Today, Mohamad is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l. to pay for his courses at the university. He is studying mechanicA. manufacturing and he is about to enter his third year. In the future, he is planning to start his career working in a large company. He hopes to earn a good income in order to help his parents with the family expenses.

loans.use: to pay for his courses at the university.

loans.name: Adis

texts.es:
Adís D. 28 años vive al sur D. L. ciudad con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades D. 2 y 3 años, con los que sueña ver surgir, teniendo los suficientes recursos para hacerlo, mediante el incremento D. su negocio, donD. se dedica a al comercio D. mercancías especialmente D. artesanías y muebles para el hogar que compra en Sampues, un municipio en el departamento D. Sucre, donD. fabrican hermosos artículos artesanales en madera, como juegos D. saL., comedor mecedoras y es muy usual este tipo D. negocios con desempeño en L. Costa Caribe, debido a que  estos productos gozan D. un  selecto mercado.  Adís en su negocio aplica el plan separe: es decir las personas encargan los artículos a los que quieren acceder,  separándolos con un dinero y gradualmente van pagándolos y al lograr reunir el precio total del producto lo reciben. 
Adis inicio su negocio hace tres años, a través D. su hermana quien L. ayudó, para que  obtuviera sus propios ingresos y apoyara al fortalecimiento D. su bienestar familiar.  Su sueño más adelante es tener un almacén especializado en artesanías D. Sampues y adquirir su casa propia. En L. actualidad Adis planea recibir su primer credikiva, con el cual inicia su vinculación a L. Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y comprará muebles típicos en madera, juegos D. saL., comedor, inversión que será exitosa por L. experiencia que tiene en este negocio y porque aplicará a su mercancía, como es usual  el “plan separe”.
texts.en:
Adís, age 28, lives to the south of the city with her husband and their two children, ages two and three.  She dreams of seeing them excel and of having sufficient resources, through the growth of her business, to do so.  She sells merchandise, especially crafts and home furniture that she buys in Sampues.  

Sampues is a municipality in the Sucre department.  They make beautiful items there that are crafted in wood.  They make things like sets for the living room, the dining room, and rocking chairs.  This type of business is very common on the Caribbean coast because these products enjoy a select market.

In her business Adís applies the layaway plan.  That is to say the people order items for those who want to have them.  They put money down, and they gradually make payments.  When they have paid the total price, they receive the items.

Adís started her business three years ago.  Her sister helped her do this so that she would get her own income and strengthen her family’s well-being.  Later, her dream is to have a store specializing in crafts from Sampues.  She also dreams of getting her own house.

Adís is now planning to receive her first Kiva loan.  This starts her connection with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  She will buy typical wood furniture and living and dining room sets.  This investment will be successful because she has experience in this business.  It will also be successful because she will apply her usual layaway plan to her merchandise.

loans.use: to buy typical wood furniture and living and dining room sets.

loans.name: Tsitsino

texts.en:
Tsitsino is 44 years old.  She is from the village of Nabakevi, West Georgia. She is married and lives with her husband, Longinoz, two sons (17 and 13 years old) and 69 year-old mother (retired). The boys study at school. 

Tsitsino and Longinoz work on the family farm. The family owns 2 milk cows and 2 calves. They produce approximately 40 kg of cheese per month. It is sold at Samtredia open market. Along with the dairy, Longinoz also works on one hectare of family-owned land, where nuts and tomatoes are grown.  On average, he sells 300 kg of nuts and 500 kg of potatoes per year. 

The average monthly income of the family is 460 Laris per month, including Tsitsino’s pension, she gets from the state because of her health problems. 

Tsitsino requested a loan for house renovations. She will purchase materials for the renovation. The biggest part of the renovation work will be done by Longinoz. The house will become more comfortable after the renovation and the living conditions of the family will improve.

loans.use: to purchase materials for house renovation

loans.name: Kevin

texts.en:
Kevin is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children.  One of her children is  in school.  Kevin has a business of a health clinic, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Kevin has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase medicine for the clinic for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Kevin hopes to generate greater profits and buy new clothes for herself. In the future, Kevin hopes to own three other health clinics. She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by assisting with her business skills.

loans.use: to purchase medicine for the clinic for resale.

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en:
Alice‘s group is comprised of three hard working women. Alice is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Alice has a business of selling food, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Alice has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase food for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Alice hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Alice hopes to build a house of her own.  Alice is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business and capital.

loans.use: to purchase food for resale.

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en:
Khalil will pay his children's schooling education fees with his requested loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l. The school management has warned him to pay the required amount before the beginning of the school year; otherwise, his children will be prohibited from pursuing their education. Khalil’s only target is to ensure a good education for his children until they enter university.

Khalil is a 31-year-old married man living with his wife and two school-aged children. He is from Lebanon. He has been working in a car wheel shop since 1996. He works hard to satisfy his family's needs.

loans.use: pay his children's schooling education fees.

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en:
Josephat is a competitive and focused 37 year-old businessman. He is married and blessed with three children. Since 1997, he has been doing photography to make life more comfortable for his family.  He uses income from this trade to supplement the income he gets from supplying schools with materials.  In the next 5 years, he wants  to have expanded his business so that he edges closer to his dream of opening up a journalism school.

He is requesting a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy a printing machine and printing papers. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for making him financially literate.

loans.use: to buy a printing machine and printing papers

loans.name: Roy's Group

texts.en:
